comments.commentBody: A study came out a couple of years ago that showed that people with messy desks not only knew where everything was, but that they were at least as productive as people with neat desks.

You have answered you own question, which you obviously realize.

"In all my research, I found no proven correlation between keeping a neat room and leading a functional, goal-oriented life."

You have even accepted the "no" and moved on. (Perhaps this is why there are, as yet, no reader comments.)

The one thing that grabs my attention is how much effort you put into 'shopping' for an answer that would satisfy your admitted longing to impose order in pursuit of your own emotional needs.

It's good to see that, in the end, you were able to give up that quest.

(For the record: I had an incredibly messy room from a very early age. I grew up to be mildly compulsive--which helped me to be a rather good computer programmer--and none the worse for having been messy.)
It is legally required that the caretaker be paid by the hour.

The answer to your question about the requirement to pay by the hour is "yes." People in low-wage jobs are paid hourly, and overtime is required to prevent employers from taking advantage of them. Creatively changing the pay scheme just to avoid the overtime is fraudulent and illegal, specifically because it takes advantage of the employee who is clearly in a weak negotiating position. Just because she says she is willing to forgo overtime in order to keep the job doesn't mean that choosing that route is legal or ethical. If she must stay late, overtime should be paid. That is the fair cost of labor.

It seems clear the letter writer actually understands all this, and even drew a clear boundary by taking the child into her own room so that the caretaker would be 'off the clock' while staying overnight. The $50 for staying over while off the clock was nice, but not necessary. The overtime is, and the case would be the same if a caretaker with a shorter commute were hired instead. That being the case, it then becomes much simpler to just keep the trusted caretaker, pay her overtime when she works over, and don't pay her when she is off the clock. For late nights, let her stay overnight off the clock. It's the decent thing to do.

Is it legally required that a caretaker be paid by the hour, as opposed to by the week or month?  If, for example, the caretaker earns $400 a week at $10 an hour for 40 hours, would it be legal for the family to agree to pay her $470 each week with the understanding that it may or may not include one date night for the parents ... and that the caretaker could stay over or not (her choice) after that one date night?  (Or, if parents go out less often, perhaps a monthly fee that included one or two potential date nights.)

I think it's wise to listen to the signals a child gives about gender orientation without weighing in, consciously or unconsciously, in either direction. I'm disturbed by the trend toward "acknowledging" that children as young as five or six are definitely "gender different." In my experience, it's just too soon to be sure.

One of our daughters began to refuse to wear girl clothing starting at age 2. From ages 2 through approximately 8 she was never in a dress; she repeatedly tried to learn to pee standing up; she insisted on a short haircut; and she strongly preferred playing with boy traditional toys over girl traditional toys. We followed her signals and let her do as she wished in every way. We also consulted with a LGBTQ psychiatrist to talk about appropriately sensitive ways of nurturing her.

Starting at 7 to 8, she began to re-orient herself toward female traditional clothing, and activities. We followed her signals.

Today, she is 16, and she is a cis teen girl She is straight, and she seems to take pride in her now womanly body.

Please wait and see with openness. If your child starts to think that you have an "expectation" in either direction, your child can unconsciously try to meet your expectation. Just as you don't want to define your child prematurely in your own mind, you should also not prematurely echo or reinforce your child's self-definition, which may be a tentative experiment rather than a permanent identity.

Perhaps, but that has nothing to do with the issue presented in the letter. It's about firing her to hire a "local" sitter. Also, i would be shocked to find a sitter who works for less than $10/hour. Even the people I know who do employ nannies/sitters off the books pay at least that and usually more.
I'm not sure why you are assuming that the interests of the infant would be sacrificed by exposure to another caring adult on occasional basis.

No, that is still taking advantage. If you can't afford to go out because you can't afford to pay your usual caregiver, then you can't afford to go out. Stay home. Or trade nights with some other couple or engage a family friend. Don't stiff your nanny in favor of some local teenager when your nanny is willing, able, available, and obviously needs the money.

And yes, you need to pay her for overnight if you are ASKING her to stay overnight. Maybe not at the full rates, but something. It is true she will get to sleep, but she is still being majorly inconvenienced and kept away from her own home and family and whatever else she might have wanted to do during that period, and unable to do anything else during that time period - in service to your family.

This is a really clear ethical issue, I see no gray areas.

I'm in shock that the writer pays her babysitter legally at all. Except for those using au pair care, as I did, I didn't know anyone in Manhattan or the suburbs who paid their full-time babysitter on the books according to the law (my kids are now young adults).

I don't mean to suggest that I approve of paying off the books. I'm only commenting that it is rare among upper-middle-class professional families in the New York area, at least according to my own personal reference group.

In fact, I had a couple of friends who sought to pay on the books, but they could not get a babysitter to agree for either tax reasons or for immigration status reasons.

In any event, here's my advice to this admirably law-abiding parent: if you can afford it, pay your babysitter at the overtime rate for the hours from 4 PM until you get home on Fridays, but don't pay her just to sleep at your house.

If you can't afford that even, or if the real issue is that you don't want her sleeping at your house, then I would have an direct and open conversation with her telling her that you don't want to take advantage of her, but you just can't afford the extra cost to keep her on Friday night, so you'll have to use a local person at a lower rate for just those few hours when you get the opportunity to go out on Friday.

Yikes. Such negativity.

Maybe those parents should take Summit off of the vacation list as well.

""Logging in from home" is talked about as a badge of honor. But it's really folks, it's a yoke."

What would happen if you did not do this? Is it a job requirement or is it just people being martyrs?
I don't do this. I go home around 5 or 6 and never check email. This has in no way hurt me at my current job or any prior jobs, even though plenty of my coworkers feel compelled to log-in every hour. I know in some workplaces it is inevitable, but in many I feel that it is self-inflicted.

This exactly. This has nothing to do with N.C. politics. (I abhor the "bathroom bills," they are absurd and hateful, but that's not the point.) That's what I did with my son, too. And even when he was a bit older - say, up to maybe age 10 or 11 - if he used a public men's room, I stood like a sentinel just outside the door - not only to be close at hand in case of any problem, but on the assumption that most men going in were likely decent human beings who would want to help if there were trouble, and they would be alerted to a young boy on his own in the bathroom and keep an eye out for him. And of course, any predator going in would be alerted that the kid's mother was right there.

BSK --

I'm not afraid of having a little boy of mine in a men's room with his father or with another trusted adult. What any rational parent doesn't like is to have his or her small child separated from her, off in a space away from her or another trusted adult. Under such circumstances, she is in no position to supervise or protect that small child.

How hard is that to understand?

Coco,

I understand that you possess an irrational fear. I'm asking why you persist in holding on to it?

I am an early childhood educator and have been for over a decade. I have a bachelors and masters in early childhood education. And I have two sons myself. Not trusting an 8-year-old to use a bathroom independently? That is irrational.

On the bathroom issue:

Until he was seven or eight, I routinely took my son into the women's room with me. There was no way I was going to have him alone in a men's room before that age. Even after that age, I stood vigilant at the door to the men's room and told him that if he wasn't out in 60 seconds I would be charging in there to check on the situation.

No one ever blinked an eye when my young son accompanied me into the women's room. Plenty of moms do as I did.

Dr M --

Like you, I am a biological and self-identified female. Also like you, I sometimes use the men's room! As long as it's a single seater and it's empty and it has a lock, why not, if the women's room has a line and the men's room does not? I've never understood why women just stand there like sheep under such circumstances.

Related anecdote: On one occasion, when my son was little, he and my husband were waiting for me and my daughters to come out of the women's room. My son and husband had finished up in the men's room a few minutes earlier. My son finally asked my husband, "Daddy, why do girls take so much longer to pee than we do?" My husband, tired from a long day, bunted and said "I don't know, son." After a long pause, my son looked at him and said, "I'll bet scientists know."

The author of the first letter purposefully refuses to use clear language. What, exactly, are the parents worried about? If they are worried about spending money in North Carolina because they disapprove of its politics, it shouldn't matter whether their children are gender-conforming, gender-nonconforming, or trans. Wrong is wrong, whether you are personally affected or not.

If the family is worried that J.G. might somehow be at risk because of the law, it matters whether J.G. is trans or simply gender-nonconforming. If the latter, I've got news for the parents: North Carolina, like every other state, has many little girls who dislike pink, long hair, and dresses, and many little boys who love pink ponies, sparkly clothing, and even (gasp!) dolls. No one would care about J.G.'s "non-conformity."

If J.G. is truly trans there is a remote possibility that the family could face some bigotry, but it is absurdly unlikely. As many posters have pointed out, small children visit the bathroom of the parent who accompanies them, and no one objects to that.

The lack of clarity in the letter and its not-so-subtle self-congratulatory tone, lead one to believe that the parents are not really concerned about the family trip at all. Their letter is a virtue signifier; its purpose is to show NYTimes readers how exquisitely sensitive and progressive these people are.

real --

Sorry, it's not just a stereotype. There are mountains of statistics to back up the notion that, as a group, residents of the former Confederate states are far less progressive on issues relating to race, gender, sexuality, reproductive rights, religion, civil rights, gun control, etc., etc., etc.

And if I didn't have statistics at the ready, I could just point anecdotally to my husband's large Southern family of origin, with whom we generally visit once a summer during family reunion season.

I'm not sure which are the scariest: the bumper stickers decorating their duded-up pickup trucks, their massive gun collections, or the chain emails they forward to us updating us on such matters as our president's Kenyan origins and how Hillary Clinton got away with murdering Vince Foster.

Believe me, I have good reason to wish it were just a stereotype.

" Something has gone seriously wrong in our country if people view kids as a lifestyle choice "
And yet Germany has one of the lowest birth rates of any country (its around 1.4) - partially because there is still stigma to full-time work for mothers, so they have way fewer kids. So they may not be calling it a lifestyle choice, but they are still exercising the choice to have very few kids, if any.

I've been on an Auto-Immune Paleo/Protocol diet for 7 months and have never felt better.  I am healing my inflamed body with food! But to do so means that I am forced to give up fine dining and this is truly heartbreaking.  I hope you show them, David Bouley! Show the world that creativity, food and healing can be a beautiful thing. I'm so excited!

I am 71 yrs old & never been on meds not even an aspirin in my house. I was brought up on non processed food and continue to eat that way.  I stopped eating "red meat" about 40yrs ago, was a vegetarian for many yrs., Occasionally, I eat good quality chicken and non farmed fish.  When my left knee was intermittently inflamed for several yrs., I discovered that it was the dairy that was the cause (Thank you CHINA STUDY).  Eating more legumes  protein & low in calories. In case you are thinking that my diet is boring and perhaps tasteless, here are just a few of my favorite ingredients: lots of garlic, olive oil, fresh herbs (favs..cilantro, parsley, rosemary, sage) fresh lemon/limes (zest and juice),red pepper flakes, pinoli nuts.  Buy your dried herbs from the health food store (much less expensive) and write the date on the glass bottle.  Buy fresh after yr even if you have a lot left. I like Indian, Thai and Japanese food as well so have their staples on my kitchen as well.  Buy Organic Shoyu instead of soy sauce.  Buy organic, do not use a microwave or teflon pans.  Avoid plastics, store all food & leftovers in glass containers as much as possible  "Just eat " even at work ...no iPhone.. or computer,  be grateful for what you are eating. Bring your lunch to work.  Eat out less and use the money you saved from a few meals to buy the best ingredients and all those glass containers. Try this: Shred fresh zucchini. add lemon zest and juice & toasted pine nuts.Takes 5 min!

I think it is grapefruit segments!

All I can say fellow Portlandia neighbor, you must have overheard me griping on the phone earlier today expressing these very same sentiments verbatim!!!!  I'm sick and tired of hearing about illegals from Mexico. It's the middle and upper-middle class wages that are being destroyed by H-1bs here in this country, not $7 or $8 /hour jobs.

Every year, after passionate statements by Members of Congress to the effect we must do something about the damage illegal immigration does to the American job market, legislation emerges purporting to do just that. But if you read such legislation it rarely addresses illegal immigration in any productive fashion. Instead it is a Christmas tree of H-1B allocations, exemptions, and opportunities pushed by corporations and recruiters. And every year we hear progress has been made dealing with immigration headaches (meaning there are more H-1B visas, less monitoring, and further flexibility). This has become a clear sham enabling Congress to announce it is open to business for fundraisers and corporate support. Rebuking Disney or Tata accomplishes nothing. Instead of sending Immigration agents to chase would-be gardeners or dishwashers through the desert they should be going through company records H-1B visa by H-1B visa verifying they were issued and are used according to regulations. And when they are not the heads of those firms, whether an American employer or a foreign recruiter, should be in court facing charges of fraud. Jailing a farmworker does little to resolve the leakage of American jobs; jailing the heads of personnel departments or vice-presidents for human resources would have a wonderful effect. Barack Obama is known as the "deportation President" for pursuing Central Americans fleeing violence while he coddles executives scamming the US through H-1B visa abuse.

At one point Clinton said the TPP was the "gold standard" of trade agreements. Competition from Sanders made her backpedal, but I'll bet the farm she does a U-turn the minute she gets in the White House.
Perhaps we should get a different president!  He's had 8 years, and he's put his money and his reputation on another Clinton.

Perhaps our President should meet with these workers rather than dining with the heads of Silicon Valley, or Indian "business" men to understand what is really going on with the future of America's middle class.
